Class ComparablePowerSort

java.lang.Object
java.util.ComparablePowerSort
public class ComparablePowerSort extends Object
This is a near duplicate of PowerSort, modified for use with arrays of objects that implement Comparable, instead of using explicit comparators.

  • Field Summary

    Fields
    Modifier and Type
    Field
    Description
    static boolean
    COUNT_COMPARISONS
    If true, count the number of comparisons
    static boolean
    COUNT_MERGE_COSTS
    If true, use the most-significant-bit trick to compute node powers; otherwise use a loop.
    static long
    totalComparisons
    Total number of comparisons
    static long
    totalMergeCosts
    Total merge costs of all merge calls

  • Field Details

    • COUNT_MERGE_COSTS

      public static boolean COUNT_MERGE_COSTS
      If true, use the most-significant-bit trick to compute node powers; otherwise use a loop.

    • totalMergeCosts

  • Constructor Details

    • ComparablePowerSort

      public ComparablePowerSort(Object[] a, Object[] work, int workBase, int workLen, int minRunLen)
      Creates a ComparablePowerSort instance to maintain the state of an ongoing sort. The workspace array slice (workBase, workLen) is a reference to the workspace array, which is used as long as it is big enough. If not, a larger array is allocated and used instead.
      Parameters:
      a - the array to be sorted
      work - a workspace array (slice)
      workBase - origin of usable space in work array
      workLen - usable size of work array
      minRunLen - minimum run length

  • Method Details

    • sort

      public static void sort(Object[] a, int lo, int hi, Object[] work, int workBase, int workLen, boolean useMsbMergeType, boolean onlyIncreasingRuns, int minRunLen)
      Sorts the given range, using the given workspace array slice for temp storage when possible. This method is designed to be invoked from public methods (in class Arrays) after performing any necessary array bounds checks and expanding parameters into the required forms.
      Parameters:
      a - the array to be sorted
      lo - the index of the first element, inclusive, to be sorted
      hi - the index of the last element, exclusive, to be sorted
      work - a workspace array (slice)
      workBase - origin of usable space in work array
      workLen - usable size of work array
      useMsbMergeType - if true, use the most-significant-bit trick
      onlyIncreasingRuns - if true, only sort increasing runs
      minRunLen - minimum run length

    • powersort

      public void powersort(int lo, int hi)
      The normal powersort algorithm, can be used in most cases.
      Parameters:
      lo - the index of the first element, inclusive, to be sorted
      hi - the index of the last element, exclusive, to be sorted
